reviewText: I didn't grow up watching BOY MEETS WORLD because it was never shown in Philippines. The first time I was able to watch an episode was at Disney Channel through cable. Since then, I'd watch a new episode everyday up until it was no longer being aired at Disney Channel. There and then I thought, I gotta have a DVD or VHS of this! But sadly, it wasn't available yet. Years later, I find it being released at last and I have to say that I'm more than elated that the production guys finally released it on DVD.Boy Meets World is simply about how a kid grows and faces everyday common challenges mostly with mistakes that he later on corrects, with or without his parent's guidance. It's a simple yet funny way of showing how growing up may not be a bed of roses to most, but it is quite an adventure. It's also about how important a family is, may it be seemingly dysfunctional or a picture of a perfect family.It is such a comic relief that it never ceased to make me laugh at the kids' wisecracks. It makes me wonder how smart alecky kids can be nowadays. Makes you think that these little critters can possibly eat you alive. Ha-ha!It was great seeing Ben Savage, the main actor portraying the lead role, grow up with this show and his strong connections with his relationships were enough to keep fans and viewers glued to their TV screens.BOY MEETS WORLD SEASON 1 DVD BOXED SET is where it all started. To fans, this is one heck of stuff you dare not overlook. To the curious onlookers, see for yourself. Believe me, it's worth every cent! Even more!

reviewText: Boy Meet's World is a fun show about a boy named Cory (Ben Savage) and his best friend Shawn (Rider Strong) going day by day learning about the world.Cory also has a brother named Eric (Will Friedle) who provides much of the comic relief along with Shawn.At school there is a soon-to-be wife Topanga (Danielle Fishel) and teacher Mr. Feeny (Willian Daniels).This is a great show that has laughs and moral lessons.This set has some good episode commentaries.If you are thinking about picking it up...do it.

reviewText: In the fall of 1997 in my third grade year of education, we had the homework of watching a 30 minute T.V. show and presented a one page summary to the class. In retrospect, I suppose this was suppose to begin warming up our minds to the idea and concept of summing up larger ideas into shorter descriptions. Yet at the time, I was eight going on nine and was just stoked to watch TV for school. So while my classmates, friends and peers were giving descriptions on shows like Rugrats, The Simpsons and Beavis & Butthead. I did a summary on the episode of Boy Meets World where Shawn allowed a girl to stay at his house because her father was beating her and my take on child and spousal abuse. The figurative record player came to a quick halt so to speak once I was done. At the time, i didn't enjoy the irony but now in retrospect as a twenty-two year old going on twenty-three I appreciate it more.Now, how was that relevant? Well,I thought it best summed up my long term love for the show Boy Meets World. Every since I was a little kid, this show has held a special place in my heart. Even now, eighteen years after discovering it, the show still reigns supreme as my all time favorite. Throughout, the main cast grows organically through seven seasons. Yet, before all the life changing growing pains that would follow, we have the first season. The subtle lessons parents Amy and Alan along with old traditionalist teacher Mr. Feeny bestow upon Cory, Shawn & Eric, which seem to still manifest serious truth and relevance into my own life. Regardless if they're being aimed at a twelve year old or not, the core truth of human emotions and growing pains are all here. Lets face it, with how the writers paired Cory and Shawn, they showed us the truest bromance of all time, before the term was even coined, with enough trouble and life lessons to nicely pan out and spread a 20 plus episode season, without becoming boring or tiresome. Now, the gang mostly steers clear of the more adult oriented trouble they would find in later seasons but again, the later seasons progressed so well because of how they laid the foundation of the show in the rest of the series. Plus the addition of class genius Minkus and hippie Topanga keep Cory & Shawn humble enough throughout.Wether you're from a younger generation, or somehow missed out on this show in the 90's, I highly recommend this product. Much like the elder Savage brother did in his time, Ben Savage summed up a decade of middle class, slacker kids just trying to find their place. Enjoy.

reviewText: I collect TV show DVD sets, and I'm very happy to say that this set, containg the first 22 episodes (the whole first season) of Boy Meets World, is no disappointment.  The episodes are in great quality, there is a "play all" feature which I find to be very uncommon among DVD sets, and there are many bonus features, like an episode from season 4, audio commentary, and more.  I was very impressed with these DVDs and hope future Boy Meets World sets come out just as impressive as this one.
summary: Great Show in a Great DVD Package

reviewText: The first season of Boy Meets World brought back many childhood memories of watching TGIF on Friday nights. Near as I can tell, the new company in charge of the Boy Meets World franchise hasn't added anything new to the original three seasons that were released previously on DVD, this DVD set features all the season one episodes + a bonus episode from season four and select episodes have commentary from Ben Savage, Rider Strong, Will Friedle, Danielle Fischell, and executive producer Mark Jacobs, which can provide an interesting experience when recounting cast stories and funny little tidbits like the hooded wardrobe Corey and Shawn where saddled with in the first season. I wish they would've included William Daniels (Mr. Feeney) because he was such an major part of the show. Instead, we get the kinda out of place Matthew Lawrence who wouldn't be part of the show until years later. Boy Meets World Season One provided a much needed travel back in time when things were not as complicated and I could be just a kid.

reviewText: This is simply a must have for all Boy Meets World fans. Back when the Disney Channel actually used to program GOOD shows during the day and early evening, I was watching Boy Meets World religiously. My friends and I identified with the dear Cory Matthews (Ben Savage), the series protagonist and younger brother to Eric Matthews (the very funny Will Friedel). All the characters are lovable though, from the school Principal Mr. Feeny (also Cory's next door neighbour) to Mr and Mrs Matthews and even Shaun's way-out father.This season shows Cory at his youngest but he is no less funny than the later seasons! I'm now 22 and still love this show :-)10/10.

reviewText: I also grew up watching this show.  I was the same age as the characters on the show.  I couldn't wait til Friday night so I could watch it!  As the characters grew up, so did I.  It seemed as if we were all facing the same problems together.  After so many years on TV you feel like you're best friends with these people.  I remember crying during the last episode because it felt as if my best friends were leaving.  This show holds so many memories for me and will be an awesome addition to my DVD collection.  I can't wait!

reviewText: This was one of my wife's favorites, back in the 90s, and so I knew she'd love it. Got it for a Christmas gift, along with the second season. I've watched this one with her and can honestly say, it's about as appealing as I recall. I'm a bit older than my wife, but I remember enjoying this when it was on Disney. I don't think I ever saw much of these earliest episodes, which were even more a family/kids show. I would probably prefer the latter ones, but I think it's great that there were sort of two different series here: one more for specifically the kids, with a good message, yet not too sacharine, and one for all the family (following seasons).

reviewText: I remember how TV Guide and other critics didn't think the show would last as long as it did, unnecessarily putting Ben Savage and his new show in brother Fred's shadow. But Ben and "Boy Meets World" would have the last laugh, running for seven consistently entertaining seasons while building a HUGE viewer fanbase. This complete first season set is somewhat of a special collector's item for casual and diehard BMW viewers, who not only can revisit the freshman season at their leisure but can also re-examine the individual episodes for continuity issues that would later plague the show. "Boy Meets World" featured a perfect blend of heart and comedy in EVERY single episode for its entire series run, and starting with this Season 1 set, can be owned on DVD!Features:Bonus Episode from Season 4: "Hair Today, Goon Tomorrow"Audio Commentary: "Cory's Alternative Friends" (Disc 1) with Ben Savage, Rider Strong, Will Friedle, Danielle Fishel and creator/executive producer Michael Jacobs.Audio Commentary: "Class Pre-Union" (Disc 2) with Ben Savage, Rider Strong, Will Friedle, Danielle Fishel and creator/executive producer Michael Jacobs.Audio Commentary: "Boy Meets Girl" (Disc 3) with Ben Savage, Rider Strong, Will Friedle, Danielle Fishel, creator/executive producer Michael Jacobs and Matthew Lawrence (5th Season's "Jack Hunter").Audio Commentary: Season 4 Bonus Episode "Hair Today, Goon Tomorrow" (Disc 3) with Ben Savage, Rider Strong, Will Friedle, Danielle Fishel, creator/executive producer Michael Jacobs and Matthew Lawrence (5th Season's "Jack Hunter").Boy Meets World - Season 2 available November 23rd!
